DOC.HEAD: Seek to Keep Secret Documents in Wrongful Firing Case
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Oil Corp. is trying to keep under wraps court documents that a former executive wants to use as proof to show the oil giant fired him for refusing to conspire in a coverup of environmental problems. Mobil argues that most of the documents are irrelevant to Valcar Bowman Jr.'s case, and says it is happy to release portions _ mostly sentences and paragraphs _ of the papers that it considers central to his claims. The nation's second-largest oil company behind Exxon Corp., denying it has anything to hide, also argues that the reports are self-criticisms encouraged by environmental regulators, and that revealing them would discourage industry attempts to be candid about environmental conditions. U.S. District Judge Harold A. Ackerman scheduled a hearing for 4 p.m. Wednesday to decide whether the documents should be kept secret. On Dec. 11, Ackerman dealt the company a setback in the case, ruling that enough evidence existed for a trial to take place on Bowman's claims. Bowman says he was wrongfully fired in April 1986 from his job as manager for environmental affairs at Mobil Chemical Co.'s Princeton, N.J. office. He lost his job, Bowman says, because he refused to ``sanitize'' environmental assessment reports about conditions at plants in the chemical division. The changes were suggested by company lawyers. Bowman was told to submit the reports to company lawyers after he refused to cooperate with what he charged was an attempt to foil investigators from examining environmental records at Mobil's Bakersfield, Calif., chemical plant. The company ordered him to remove records following a raid at a Torrance, Calif., plant, Bowman alleged. Mobil denies wrongdoing, calling Bowman's claims a ``garden-variety'' wrongful firing lawsuit. The company said it had a right to terminate Bowman, and did so as part of an economic cutback. Mobil also denies seeking to mask environmental problems, and accused Bowman of releasing secret company documents to competitors. Mobil also says changes in the environmental reports were minor matters of wording and typographical errors. The focus of Wednesday's hearing is expected to be 20 or so assessment reports, some filed by each side. They are ``the heart of the case,'' said Bowman's attorney, Stephen B. Wiley. The reports are ``all directly relevant to the proceeding and should be available to the public,'' he said. ``It's a public proceeding.'' Wiley said Mobil was seeking to exclude the public from Wednesday's hearing, but Mobil attorney Richard Reibstein denied that. ``The reason we're protecting the privacy of these reports is so we can continue to do them,'' said Mobil Chemical's general counsel, Ron Neill. ``The whole objective here is in the public interest.'' If companies felt their self-criticisms could ever be splashed across newspapers, they would be discouraged from making such evaluations, he said.
